awd_titl_txt: Continuing Operations Proposal: The United States Polar Rock Repository as a Research Tool for Understanding Antarctica's Geological Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Geological field expeditions in polar regions are logistically difficult, financially expensive, and can have a significant environmental impact on pristine regions.  The scarcity of exposed rock outcrop in Antarctica, which is 98% ice-covered, makes previously collected rock samples very valuable to the science community. The U.S. Polar Rock Repository (PRR) was established at the Ohio State University in 2003 to meet the need for preserving rock, dredge, and terrestrial core samples from polar areas. The PRR curates geological samples collected primarily from Antarctica and the southern oceans and acquires these collections through donations from institutions and scientists.  The existence of the PRR allows samples collected at a high financial cost to be used to their full scientific potential. Currently more than 40,000 samples are available as no-cost loans for research, education, and museum exhibits.  In addition to the physical samples, the PRR archives supporting materials from the collector, such as images of the samples, field maps, air photos, thin sections, and any associated bibliography/DOIs.  Scientists, graduate students, and undergraduate students routinely use samples from the PRR for their research projects.  The PRR also freely loans an educational 'rock box' that contains representative rock, fossil and mineral samples, books and activities about geology and Antarctica to K-12 teachers from across the United States. 

The PRR provides stewardship of polar rock sample collections and metadata. It is one of the few lending rock repositories to allow destructive research techniques to be used on samples. The PRR website and in-house digital metadata archive provides for global dissemination of data and also a unique resource for pilot studies, proposal preparation and field logistics planning. The PRR fulfills the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR), Antarctic Data Management (2009) directive of providing free, full and open access to metadata and collections. Over the course of the next 5 years, the PRR will work proactively with the research community to acquire scientifically valuable rock collections and supplementary materials that will enhance the PRR collection. Samples will be cataloged following standard curatorial practices and will be made discoverable through the public facing portion of the Collections Management system developed at the Byrd Polar Climate and Research Center. The preservation of these physical samples, along with archiving of associated metadata, and inclusion of DOI?s in a discoverable online database, allows for transparency and reproducibility in polar earth science research. The Collections Management System will continue to be updated and improved.  The Curator will continue to advance the discoverability of the PRR by attending meetings, creating a webinar and contacting scientists about new collections at the facility. The PRR will continue to fulfill loans of samples and enhance the links with other respositories and data management entities to better enable interdisciplinary research. Educational outreach to K-12 schools will continue with the 'polar rock box' being freely available to US schools.

por.por_cntn:
Geological field expeditions in polar regions are logistically difficult, financially expensive, and can have a significant environmental impact on pristine regions. In addition, the lack of outcrop in Antarctica (98% ice-covered) makes previously collected rock samples very valuable to the science community. The Polar Rock Repository (PRR) curates and loans geologic samples from polar regions to researchers and educators. The National Science Foundation - Office of Polar Programs established the PRR in part to avoid redundant sample collection and thus reduce the environmental impact of polar research. The PRR offers the research community an important resource for developing new research projects. The online database and in-house digital data archive provide a unique logistics planning resource by providing detailed outcrop and field logistics information (camp locations, transport methods, weather conditions, etc.). The PRR acquires rock collections through donations from institutions and scientists and makes these samples available as no-cost loans. As of March 2023, the PRR collection included >60,000 samples from rocks, unconsolidated material, cores, marine dredges and a small collection of  lichen and moss.  The PRR acquired 21 sample collections during the award period.

 

To make the samples available to researchers around the country, the PRR continued to improve an online database and shopping cart feature for researchers to request samples for analyses. An advanced search engine for the PRR allows scientists and the public to “drill down” into search results using categories and look-up object fields. Results can be viewed in a table, downloaded as a spreadsheet, or plotted on an interactive map that supports display of satellite imagery and bathymetry layers.  The layers are presented in a Google Maps-like interface and users can pan-and-zoom to any location on the Antarctic continent.  There are multiple ways to request samples.  Users can check the boxes next to the Thumbnail images or the Search Results List or click on the ‘Request Sample’ icon on an individual sample result page to place samples in the Shopping Cart.  During this award, almost 4,000 samples have been used for research and more than 9000 for educational outreach.

 

A post-doctoral scholar during the final year of the award worked collaboratively with the Columbia University Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory PetDB database (petrological database) to incorporate geochemistry data from >1,900 PRR samples into the database.  Polar geochemical data have been used to infer past climatic conditions, mantle dynamics and a host of other research topics. Adding geochemistry data from PRR samples to the PetDB dataset will facilitate global correlations, identify samples for paleoclimate proxies, and enhance analytical reproducibility.  The addition of the geochemical data to the PetDB database also fulfills Priority 1b for the Strategic Vision for Antarctic and Southern Ocean Research by making records available that can be used to understand the processes and rates of past ice sheet change. 

 

Research conducted from using samples and data at the PRR resulted in 40 peer reviewed publications plus abstracts were given at meetings.  In addition, 17 Ph.D., Master’s, and Honor’s theses were produced by students. The services and samples provided by the PRR provided significant monetary and environmental cost benefits to the US Antarctic Science Program.  During this award, use of samples from the Polar Rock Repository has resulted in saving millions of dollars in logistics costs plus the associated costs of Antarctic support personnel by not having to visit Antarctic outcrops to recollect samples.

 

Broader Impacts:

Outreach is an important part of the PRR’s activities.  Teachers may borrow a no-cost “Polar Rock Box” containing 45 representative rock, fossil, and mineral samples, books and activities about geology and Antarctica.  The Polar Rock Box is ordered online from the PRR website.  During this project, more than 11,000 students (mostly elementary and middle school) from 23 states used the Polar Rock Box (154 rock boxes were sent out) in their earth science curriculums.  During COVID, a virtual (3D) rock box was developed for online use by educators, viewed >14,000 times. The PRR was also active in community outreach with both PRR tours and public offsite events, (e.g., the Ohio State Fair, Wexner Center for the Arts, COSI, etc.), reaching >11,000 participants.
